name: cutout
content:
cutout noun [C]
(SHAPE)
Add to word list
Add to word list
a shape that has been cut out from something, especially a flat one that can stand vertically: Fed-up residents have resorted to using cardboard cutouts of children placed near the edge of the road so that passing drivers will see them and slow down. I had my photo taken with a life-size cut-out of the actor. See also
cardboard cutout
a space made in something such as a material or object by cutting part of it out: You can make cut-outs in the dough with cookie cutters if you like. The glow of the candle shines through star-shaped cutouts.
More examplesFewer examplesVisitors to the casino are encouraged to have a picture taken with a life-sized cut-out of the boxing champion.Magazine cutouts, often depicting women, decorate the salon walls.She was standing next to a cut-out of the President.The one-piece swimsuits with plunge fronts and cut-outs seemed to be designed only for those with flat, toned tummies.

cutout noun [C]
(SAFETY DEVICE)
a device that, for safety reasons, stops or interrupts a circuit, used, for example, in a motor or engine: A safety cut-out had switched off the power when she opened the hatch. a cutout fuse/switch
More examplesFewer examplesSafety features include an anti-scald cut-out, which switches off the heater at a pre-set maximum temperature.

(of a shape) having been cut out from something: The model scenery even had a green mountain and a sky with cutout stars.
(of an object, piece of clothing) having holes in it made by cutting parts out: Forget bikinis, there's only one item to wear on the beach this summer and that's a cut-out swimsuit.

a shape cut out, or to be cut out, from something: This children’s book has animal cutouts.
